title: MAMBO Pop Up
historyDescription: In 1953, Rojas Pinilla led a coup d'état with which he established a Military Junta as a government during the following years, which were characterized by the restriction of freedoms and rights. However, during the military regime important events were carried out works for the modernization process of Colombia, among them, the foundation of the Museum of Modern Art.

With an act signed by intellectuals, artists and ministers, the creation of the Museum was decreed in 1955. Before the construction of the current building, the Museum lasted several years without a fixed headquarters, moving through different areas of the city such as the National University and the District Planetarium, among others. The critic and manager Marta Traba promoted the opening of the Museum to the public from 1962 until his expulsion from the country in 1967, for questioning

The military intervention in the University where the museum had its headquarters. In 1969, Gloria Zea took over the direction of the Museum when it left the university campus, Zea managed several headquarters until finally a lot was acquired in 1974 where the current headquarters was built of the Museum between 1979 and 1985 (Zea, 1994, p.50 - p.78). The Museum building is located in the center of the city and is adjacent to the Bicentennial Park, the

Parque de la Independencia and the District Planetarium. It was designed by the architect Rogelio Salmona as a sample of the geometric criteria of abstract art and modern architecture in Bogotá (Moreno and Medina, 1994. p.88 - p.92). MAMBO, for 57 years, has worked to investigate, preserve and promote the manifestations of modern and contemporary art. In 2016, the artist Claudia Hakim assumed the direction of the Museum with a new team that proposes a Museum with all citizens and with various proposals for curatorship, museography and education.
author: Oscar Monsalve
authorContent: He was the official photographer of the Museum for several years, consolidating an important visual memory of modern and contemporary art in Colombia. In this series of photographs, you can see the construction of the current museum headquarters and the assembly of some representative exhibitions.
forWhatContent:
Museums are democratizing, inclusive and polyphonic spaces for critical dialogue about the past and the future. Recognizing and addressing the conflicts and challenges of the present, they safeguard artifacts and specimens for society, safeguard diverse memories for future generations , and guarantee equal rights and equal access to heritage for all peoples. Museums are non-profit making. 
 They are participatory and transparent, and work in active collaboration with and for various communities in order to collect, preserve , investigate, interpret, expose, and expand understanding of the world, with the purpose of contributing to human dignity and social justice, global equality and planetary well-being. (Icom, 2019)
proposal: This section proposes to reflect on the value of museums, taking into account the new global definition that is still under discussion and the history of the Museum of Modern Art (MAMBO)
questions: Why was the creation of the Museum of Modern Art important for the modernization of the country?
How do you think museums expand understanding of the world?
What is it to be democratic, inclusive and polyphonic?
Why do museums seek to safeguard diverse memories for future generations?
How can a museum contribute to human dignity, social justice and planetary well-being?

title: Modern Art in the World
historyDescription: Modern art was a process of transformation in which painters, sculptors and writers of that period sought new forms of representation. It occurred approximately between 1850 and 1970, as a consequence of the Industrial Revolution, the French Revolution and the fall of the monarchy The artists rebelled against the Renaissance inspiration of academic art,

based on religion, Greek mythology, portraiture and still life, to capture their own interests and questions in their works. (Gallerix, 2009) The invention of the camera and photography around the 1830s prompted the artists to break with the tradition of figurative representation to create works from their personal aesthetics.

The European avant-gardes are an example of the different formal and conceptual explorations of the artists of this periodor those who experimented with new themes, materials, techniques and processes, expanding the concept of art, its limits and functions. (Play Academy, 2016)
author: Edouard Manet
authorContent: He was one of the forerunners of impressionism and modern painting. This work called Olympia, an ironic reference to Greek history, generated controversy for presenting a nude woman who apparently was a sex worker, defying the codes morals and the tradition of the female nude in art.
forWhatContent: In this section it is proposed that teachers and students reflect on the relationship between the Industrial Revolution, the French Revolution and the origin of Modern Art that rebels against historical tradition.
didYouKnow: Photography radically modified the materiality of works of art, the way of producing images and of relating to the world.
questions: Why was it important for artists of the time to question classical beauty ideals?
Why is rebelling and questioning important for artistic creation?
Why do you think there should be spaces for free expression?

title: Modern Art in Colombia
historyDescription: At the beginning of the 20th century the first examples of modern painting are seen in Colombia, the artists sought new forms of painting and sculpture, appropriating the heritage of Dadaism and Cubism to detach themselves from the aesthetics of the beautiful.

Colombia was also the scene of the global debate between capitalism vs. communism and the impulse to transform its context led artists to question established morality and propose works of art with transgressive political content.
The desire to unlinkColombian art history of the European tradition, motivated the artists of the “Bachué” group to investigate symbols and images of local indigenous and peasant expressions.

01 From the 50s influenced by political events such as El Bogotazo, the artists assumed strong political positions, expressed in the confrontation between those who defended socialist realism and the defense of

an own identity, against those who supported abstract expressionism. This contrast between abstraction and figurative art was decisive for the artists of the sixties and the origin of contemporary art. (Jaramillo, 2012. p. 129 - p. 206)
author: Alejandro Obregón
authorContent: From the age of 6 he lived in the country, he was part of the Barranquilla Group and was a benchmark of modern and contemporary painting in Colombia. He created images that debated between figuration and abstraction (figurative expressionism), highlighting the expressive brushstrokes and the stain of color. This emblematic work is a reflection of his interest in denouncing the harshness of the national reality.
forWhatContent: In this section it is proposed that teachers and students reflect on the relationship between the political context and art, and the need to build nationalist discourses in the face of foreign influences.
didYouKnow: The period known as La Violencia, characterized by clashes between the liberal and conservative parties, prompted artists to demonstrate in the face of the social and political situation.

keyConcepts.title: cold war
keyConcepts.content: Military, political and cultural confrontation that took place between 1945 and 1989 between the western bloc, represented by the United States in defense of capitalism against the Soviet Union (U.R.R.S) in defense of communism.

img.alt: Unknown author. Photograph of the Berlin Wall. 1989. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the GNU license.

keyConcepts.title: el bogotazo
keyConcepts.content: Popular revolts that took place in Bogotá after the assassination of Jorge Eliécer Gaitán on April 9, 1948, which originated the period known as La Violencia in which the liberal and conservative parties clashed.

img.alt: Sady González. Tram on fire. 1948. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: socialist realism
keyConcepts.content: Artistic current that emerged in the 1920s in the Soviet Union, motivated by the representation of reality for ideological purposes and often with content of denunciation. It was influential in the creation of Latin American movements that defended social realism as an instrument against imperialism.

img.alt: Unknown author. Monument to the fighters of the October revolution. in Almaty, Kasakhstan. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public domain.

keyConcepts.title: North American expressionism
keyConcepts.content: It is considered the first current of abstract art in the United States, characterized by pictorial works on large-format canvases where paint was thrown spontaneously, creating free and expressive images. This current was opposed to socialist realism and was used as a tool for expanding the ideas expressed by the capitalist bloc in the Cold War.

img.alt: Jackson Pollock. Head. 1938-1941. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the CC BY 2.0 license.

keyConcepts.title: communism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system proposed by Karl Marx in which there is no private property and the profit produced by the workers is distributed equitably, all means of production being administered by the State.

img.alt: John Jabez Edwin Mayall. Portrait of Karl Marx. 1875. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public domain.

keyConcepts.title: capitalism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system proposed by Adam Smith where the capital produced by the means of production from the labor force is a private person or company; this being the engine of the market economy and what differentiate socioeconomic classes.

title: Conceptual Art in the World
historyDescription: This trend appeared around the 1960s and consists of recognizing art not only for its aesthetic value but also for its intellectual value. Conceptual art does not use a specific medium since it does not depend on the form but on the content and capacity of communicate an idea, so it can be an installation,

Photography, ready-made, performance, graphic work or video-art. Conceptual artists are interested in their context, they appropriate a theme and by means of a work they resignify objects, images and concepts. In Land Art, for example, interest in space led artists to alter

The landscape and using the available materials; on the other hand, in Minimalism the artists were interested in perception, moving away from realistic representation. (Tate, nd) 01 The period between the 60s and 70s was characterized by great social changes generated by various activist movements around the world such as:

feminist and LGBT movements, anti-racist organizations, demonstrations against the war in Vietnam and the riots in Paris in May 68. In conceptual art, problems of the social, political, religious environment are often identified and denounced or ecological, frequently using irony and satire.
In addition, the very meaning of art is questioned, stating that the artist's subjectivity defines what art is and the viewer completes the work with his interpretation. (EcuRed, 2019)
author: Cildo Merireles
authorContent: He is recognized for his contributions to Latin American conceptual art, with works made from the analysis of Latin American economic and political systems. In this series, the artist recreates a series of counterfeit bills to reflect on capital, power and exploitation.

title: Conceptual Art in Colombia
history: Why did conceptual art emerge in Colombia?
historyDescription: In Colombia, as in most Latin American countries, there was a state of social and political tension reflected in a period of restricted democracy that began with the Rojas Pinilla coup in 1953 and continued for 16 years in the period known as National Front.

Conceptual art arises as a reaction against the arbitrariness of artistic and political institutions, which is why some artists, such as Feliza Bursztyn, were persecuted and had to go into exile. Conceptual artists in Colombia experimented with new media and formats, combining different artistic disciplines such as ready-made, photography and installation, among others.

01 The artists created collectives such as El Grupo de Arte Experimental 'El Sindicato' to question individualism and propose new ideas about society, consigned in their manifestos (Barrios, A. 1999). The use of means of reproduction such as photocopies and serigraphs was a tool for

Take art out of official places and democratize its creations. The debates and controversies associated with the National Artists' Hall show the desire of artists to transgress this institution, which until 1978 recognized the proposals of conceptual art, granting it the first prize to the work “A-la-cena con Zapatos” by “El Sindicato” (Herrera, 2011)
author: Bernardo Salcedo
authorContent: He was one of the pioneers of conceptual art in Colombia. He worked combining elements of painting, writing and sculpture, to generate questions about the socio-historical context. This work arises as a tribute to the life of Dante Alighieri and his muse Beatriz Portinari with whom he never consummated his love. This work was awarded for reflecting the new proposals of conceptual art, with the use of minimalist volumes and irony in its name.

didYouKnow: One of the first performances in Colombia was carried out by a group of artists who took down their paintings from the National Artists' Hall and later burned some coffins in the center of Bogotá.

title: Contemporary Art in the World
historyDescription: Contemporary art arises in the second half of the 20th century and is characterized by a multiplicity of theoretical and technical approaches. Contemporary artists take art practices to their limits, and seek to generate a reflection in the viewer criticism from his personal research.

Artists are beginning to cover the different fields of knowledge in a transdisciplinary way. Globalization and access to the internet have allowed the expansion of new technologies, providing the public

a new approach to the image through the screen (Ampudia, M. 2016). The incursion of technology and new media propose different relationships between works of art, the public and artists, resulting in frequent proposals interactive and relational like the happening and the performance.
Many times, in contemporary art, the viewer becomes a participant in the work, offering them the possibility of immersing themselves in environments that involve all the senses. (Pazos, A. 2018)

authorContent: He is one of the most sought-after contemporary artists on the art market. He makes this series of sculptures with animals dissected in formaldehyde to question the public about the ephemeral and the limits between life and death.

title: Contemporary art in Colombia
history: Expressions of contemporary art in Colombia
historyDescription: Beginning in the 50s, Colombia experienced important social transformations marked by rapid urban growth, caused by displacement and modernization. The new representations of the city were a recurring theme for artists such as Fernell Franco, Carlos Caicedo or Dora Franco, who they used photography artistically, connecting with other areas of visual production such as design, advertising, popular graphics and the media.

The struggles for gender rights and freedoms motivated the creation of works around the body, homoeroticism and sexuality, opening in art a space for free expression. Artists such as María Evelia Marmolejo, Luis Caballero or Karen Lamassonne,

they made works around their gender identity, combining differenttechniques such as drawing, video and performance. The political and social tensions of the 60s and 70s, prompted the production of works that questioned the patriotic, religious and cultural symbols; this is reflected in the works of Antonio Caro and Bernardo Salcedo. (Jaramillo, Suarez and Wills, 2018)

The Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá - MAMBO was connected with the Museums of Modern Art of Medellín, Cali and Barranquilla, to make visible artists from different regions. Two decisive events for Contemporary Art in Colombia happened at MAMBO: the exhibition Environmental Spaces which introduced the installation and the Atenas Salons that strengthened the emergence of contemporary art. (Jaramillo, 2012)
author: Beatriz González
authorContent: She is one of the most recognized artists in Colombia, her work has explored the limits between painting and sculpture, using popular culture images in everyday objects to communicate her reflections on the Colombian context and the problems associated with it. conflict, gender and landscape. In this work, the artist intervenes a wooden bed with a religious image.
forWhatContent: In this section it is proposed that teachers and students reflect on the particular expressions of contemporary art and the role of artists in the Colombian social, political and cultural context.
didYouKnow: In the 1991 Constitution the State recognizes its duty to promote access to art and culture in society as a guarantee of the rights of all citizens to the free expression of their identity.
